summary.title: IoT Threat Model
summary.description: For a standard home automation setup that includes a few smart devices connected to a local network.  Common router, simple IoT devices and appliances like a "smart" fridge.

threats.title: Man In The Middle (MITM) Attacks
threats.description: Someone could connect in between the router and internet node and attempt to intercept data or sensitive information

threats.title: Abusing out of date firmware
threats.description: If a user hasn't regularly updated their firmware, they could abuse known hacks.

text.text:
A bad actor could potentially 
try connecting to the router 
directly, thus potentially having 
access to the automation 
server's api, or directly to the 
IoT interface

data.name:
A bad actor could potentially 
try connecting to the router 
directly, thus potentially having 
access to the automation 
server's api, or directly to the 
IoT interface

threats.title: API access
threats.description: If there is an assumed Trusted Boundary at the router / network level, it is very likely that you don't have additional authentication / authorization at a home server level.

threats.title: Root on home server
threats.description: The ultimate goal with most hacks is to get root access, if a bad actor can access an api with no authentication, would they be able to install malware with higher privileges that gives them easy access to control all devices.

threats.title: Abusing out of date firmware
threats.description: If a user hasn't regularly updated their firmware, they could abuse known hacks.

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #15:
Usage may resemble legitimate application usage but leads to exhaustion of resources
threats.mitigation: Mitigation or prevention such as providing backoff, resource management and avoiding forced deadlock
